title: Before 20 December 2019, will the U.S. Congress present the president with legislation banning the manufacture, possession, and/or sale of high capacity magazines for firearms?
possible_answers: Yes, and the president will sign it before 1 January 2020
Yes, and the president will veto it before 1 January 2020
Yes, and the president will neither sign nor veto it before 1 January 2020
preds: Impeachment over takes Senate.  Senate does not take up legislation on democrat gun reforms.
Congress is too focused on impeachment.
Barring a major coordinated attack by multiple terrorists using assault weapons and associated knee-jerk legislation, I feel that the Senate has no intention of passing a gun control bill
Very few sure things in life, but this seems like one of them.

There are 110 bills with the word gun in them. Five have made it to committee, and of those, two relating to concealed carry (pro carry across state lines into other CC states) and a bipartisan background bill have more support than the high capacity magazine bill does. The bill was introduced in Feb/19 and passed committee in Sep/19. It now needs to pass both the House and Senate. Since then the House has been focused on Impeachment. Before being presented to the president, it has to pass the Senate (assuming it passes the house), where is unlikely to pass. All of the 161 sponsors in the House are Dems, and there are only 47 Dems in the Senate, where they require 60 votes to pass. Based on this, Dem Senators are unlikely to force a vote that would likely fail and set the process back.
Before 20 December 2019, will the U.S. Congress present the president with legislation banning the manufacture, possession, and/or sale of high capacity magazines for firearms?

Keeping this at 100% "no" because of continued indications that the White House is consumed with the impeachment inquiry and is extremely unlikely to pursue gun control legislation [1], mostly because this would antagonize many people in his base at a time that Trump needs the full support of said base. No.  This just isn't going to happen.  While all murders are tragic and sad, this is more of an emotional issue than a statistical issue.  In 2018, more people were murdered by body parts (hands, feet, fists), blunt tools (hammers, etc), or knives than rifles of any kind.  These numbers come from the FBI's own reporting.  In 2017, the latest year I was able to find data for, about 10,874 deaths were directly attributable to drunk driving.

Given lack of enough public support to force through a high capacity magazine ban it is unlikely. What Are The Chances For Any Of These Bills? These three bills becoming law is unlikely, given the current make-up of the GOP-led Senate, where a filibuster-proof majority is needed for passing new gun laws. Two background check bills passed by the House in February have been languishing in the Senate ever since. However, a federal “red flag” bill could be an exception. And President Donald Trump could be a game-changer in this debate. As Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told radio host Hugh Hewitt, he would not put a gun bill on the Senate floor unless Trump said he would sign it. And over the weekend, Sen. Roy Blunt, R-Mo., reinforced the Senate majority’s stance on NBC’s Meet the Press: “We’re not going to vote on bills on the Senate floor that the President is not willing to sign.” Thus far, Trump has not made clear what, if any, gun legislation he would support. An NPR/PBS/Marist poll from July found that 96% of Democrats and 84% of Republicans favor universal background checks that would include private sales. And a recent Guns & America/APMResearch/Call to Mind survey finds that more than 70% of Americans (and 67% of gun owners) support so-called “red flag” or ERPO laws.
https://wamu.org/story/19/09/20/a-closer-look-at-the-3-gun-control-bills-congress-is-tackling-this-week/

The bill hasn't even passed the Senate where the Republicans will vote it down with their superior numbers.

I did my first forecast without reading the other forecaster's forecasts and in a few short minutes.  I have now read the other forecasts, which are much more pessimistic than mine.  Originally, I had the chance of a bill NOT passing at about 80-85 percent.  Then, I remembered McConnell stating he was waiting for the president's lead so I reduced it to 75 percent.    After further thought, I realized McConnell's comment was just a few days after the last mass shooting.  That was about a month ago, and other events have taken over the news so there is less impetus to pass any gun bill right away.  Much of the next  the gun debate will be driven by news coverage of additional mass shootings.   There seems to be one major mass shooting (more than 6 or 7 people dead) every three or four months.  (The mass shootings of only three or four people dead get a lot less attention--even when children are involved.  I know because one happened not far from where I live a few months ago,  and it is all but forgotten.)    Thus, after looking at Wikipedia to see how many mass shooting occur each year and if they occur more or less in winter,  i think on average there should be about one large scale mass shooting between now and December 20.  

The second issue is will any gun legislation include a ban on high capacity magazines as opposed to just red flag laws or background checks favored overwhelmingly by Republicans.  I found only about 40 to 45 percent of Republicans support a ban on high capacity magazines. Impeachment will have an effect.  Trump wants to endear himself to the base so he will not back a high capacity magazine ban if only 43 percent -- or less of the conservative wing of his party-- support such a ban.  Also, the gun manufacturers oppose such a ban.   However, Trump has been saying he wants the government to get on with the business of government rather than focus on impeachment.  Therefore, he would welcome the chance to sign a gun bill that made the country feel safe in a high publicity  White House ceremony after a mass shooting.  The end result?   Unfortunately, an 80 percent chance -- or higher -- that there will be a significant mass shooting in the next two months sufficient to generate substantial media attention.   There is maybe a 20 percent chance, at best, that it would result in legislation.  (So far nothing has passed, but the rising frequency of mass shootings seems to be having an effect, .e.g., McConnell's comments.)  However, it is highly unlikely, maybe 20 percent a best, that such legislation would include a high capacity magazine ban with Trump in the White House.  So, ninety chance no bill.  But, Trump will sign it if it passes  since McConnell says he will only put to a vote a bill  that Trump will sign.   (.8 x .2 x .2= .032)  or about 96 percent no.

The contradictory forces are  general public opinion, republican public opinion, large gun manufactures and likelihood of additional mass shootings.  Sen. Mitchell has said he will only allow a vote legislation Trump says he will sign.  Thus, it is a binary choice and Trump's call.   The NRA leadership seems to be the key factor, and they seem to following the gun manufacturers' money.  That is what the current NRA scandal seems to be about.
Impeachment is overtaking everything.  So there is no space/time left for anything else let alone a bill that would be controversial for most politicians that support it.
Impeachment is the only thing on Congress's plate until the election.
This sort of legislation is often proposed, rarely voted upon, passed perhaps 1x per 20 - 30 years.
Updating my forecast due to the other distractions at the forefront of the political scene

Add in that he could also stall on the issue if there is no clear political advantage.

I agree with @Emil and others on this question, but I believe others are not properly incorporating the time deadline into the question. For example, a session of Congress is far longer than the 2 month period of this question which means that when you adjust for time the probability in a Congress-month is far lower. Moreover, the life of any of the bills described is far, far longer than a couple months, so you need to take that into account too.  I disagree with the inside view posted by others, because these school shootings etc have been taking place since I was in college several years ago. If this issue is important now, then it was important last year and last decade. It's unclear why recent events have created pressure that will catalyze a bill within the next two months before our deadline.

McConnell will not move without Trump, and Trump will not move without the NRA. The House had HR 8 on the floor - there have been 4 roll calls with the last one (Feb 2009) still having 190 nays - not quite 1/2 of the House membership - clearly there existed no bipartisan support back then.
And HR 8 only addressed eliminating private party sales without first going to licensed dealer for background check to be performed - a bridge too far for 190 House members. 
It was sent to the Senate in March and it sits on the Leg. calendar;  I find no action taken up by the Senate since. The three measures passed by House Judiciary on Sep 10 includes magazine restrictions. If HR 8 background checks can't be supported, nothing to do with tangible components of the weaponry itself is likely supportable. Election-year issue, regrettably, with no intent of passage.
Banning before additional restrictions is too great a step.

This is a pretty entrenched issues with little movement for years, the most recent tragedies have not lead to much change in the way the national debate has evolved. The only reason signing a bill is more likely than the other yes answers is coordination affects.

https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/07/us/politics/congress-assault-weapons-ban.html?nl=todaysheadlines&emc=edit_th_190908?campaign_id=2&instance_id=12073&segment_id=16839&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1&regi_id=778250250908 " . . . the circuitous route to passage taken by the assault weapons ban 25 years ago illustrates just how perfectly the legislative stars must align for contentious gun measures to become law. It also shows what such an effort entails — true bipartisanship, a committed White House, a readiness on all sides to compromise and a willingness by some lawmakers to take a significant political risk. “When I voted for it, I actually had to have police protection for six months,” Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, said of the backlash to his vote for the assault weapons ban. “It was really nasty.” The consequences of the vote were so severe — Democrats lost the House after four decades of control, with the assault weapons ban ranking high among the reasons — that Congress has been unable to advance major gun safety legislation since. The epidemic of mass shootings and the rise of effective gun control advocacy groups have steadily shifted attitudes. Most Democrats are again willing to push ahead with universal background checks and other limits on gun ownership, though few are talking about trying to reinstitute the assault weapons ban. Congressional Republicans remain, for the most part, opposed to sweeping proposals, particularly without knowing where President Trump will land on the issue.
. . . 
After the school massacre in 2012 in Newtown, Conn., Democrats and a handful of Republicans took a run at expanding background checks but came up short while a proposal to reinstate an assault weapons ban badly failed. Congress has made some very modest improvements to the background check system since then, but the coming weeks will be the most serious gun control push in years. The Democrat-led House has already passed its own measure expanding background checks, but only eight Republicans — including Representatives Upton and King — backed that bill.  . . . Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, has said he would put on the floor only a measure the president supports. Despite a summer of mass shootings, it will be difficult for Congress and the White House to come together on major gun restrictions as they did for that moment in 1994.
~~~~~~~

I apparently missed the party, on this coming out, which makes me terribly terribly sad. And I just realized that I have been forgetting to use the outside view itself.  @Emil, I am going to steal your format because I like it.  ~~~
Outside View
~~~ 
From the broader context of bills being passed through Congress, most of them do not get through. However, back in 1994, Bill Clinton did pass a bill that did stop Assault Rifles from being sold. Which lasted until 2004. Also, back last year, legislation was introduced to stop the making of 3D Printed guns which DJT did say "Does not make much sense (allowing them)". There is also some records of trump saying, doesn't the NRA have enough guns, when he was running for office. Though, he did allow them to happen.  So I am going to go out and say, there is a 94% chance of no ~~Mid Outside view?~~ On the porch maybe? The New York times just released an article on the growing number on the grades of Congress and the NRA. Dissent is growing in Congress with the Number of F's being at 243. Now to get through Congress you need about 218 votes. Let's assume that some of that 243 will not vote against the bill. And it drops to, 180 since this would be an aggressive ban. So we can drop the probability of No to about 91 percent. Given that a bill was passed through Congress in February.  As of February of 2018, The NRA gave 52 Senators A-'s as far as grades to the congress. Now that being said, could 3 of them be swayed a little bit? Maybe? After all, the 1994 bill got through the Senate at a 52-48 passing bill.  Therefore being somewhat doable maybe. That being said, a bill was introduced in January and it is still in committee.  Given the high frequency of assault weapon attacks, maybe one will happen in a state where there is enough pressure for a senator to change his mind. So I am going to drop mine to 83%. ~~~
Inside view
~~~ 
Time kills us all, that is the truth. And the hard part of this bill being passed is, is  there enough time for the Senators to be swayed, and we are not in an election year so there is that I am going to upgrade my No to be at 89%.  The  chance of Trump ignoring it is slightly higher, and I could see him vetoing it at 4% [1]. https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/31/trump-3-d-guns-751249

"Assault-style" rifles and / or high capacity rifles. There will still be 17 shot Glock mags etc. I think it will be a trim of rifle mags from 30 to say, 5.

It is useful to first consider whether such legislation has ever been passed before - and it has been, as part of the 1994 Federal Assault Weapons Ban. This substantially alters the calculus in favor of this being more likely. However, some caveats: This was a small part of a tough on crime bill that was popular with both parties, it narrowly passed by a 52-48 vote in the Senate (this Senate had more than 52 Democrats), it garnered the votes of 46 House Republicans (which is nearly unimaginable now), and was signed into law by President Clinton (a Democrat).  Today, the House is also controlled by Democrats and it seems likely to pass such a ban - such legislation is already making its way through the chamber. However, the Senate is controlled by Republicans 53-47 and President Trump is a Republican. This legislation would not pass the Senate unless it were supported by Mr. McConnell, which in turn depends on President Trump's support for the legislation - and Mr. McConnell is unlikely to bring anything that President Trump does not support to the Senate floor, so the possibility of this legislation being passed but vetoed by Trump seems like the least likely option. The option that the President would neither sign nor veto such legislation if it were passed also seems fairly implausible, since Trump would almost certainly be keen on showing strength/decisiveness by taking action one way or another. As for President Trump's stance/thinking: despite showing some support for nonspecific gun reform (which may or may not include a high capacity magazine ban) after the recent spate of mass shootings, Trump appears to have backed off after a phone call with NRA chief Wayne LaPierre. Of course, Trump can change his mind again - as he has often done in the past - in fact, he banned bump stocks in December 2018, even though this move was opposed by the NRA. But it appears as if most of the reforms currently being considered by the Trump Administration are much softer than outright bans - strengthened background checks, red flag laws and such. An outright ban on high capacity magazines seems unlikely - but not implausibly so, as Trump is very prone to changing his mind and the Republicans in Congress will probably follow his lead.

https://www.npr.org/2019/08/13/750656174/the-u-s-once-had-a-ban-on-assault-weapons-why-did-it-expire Federal Assault Weapons Ban The Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Use Protection Act or Federal Assault Weapons Ban (AWB) was a subsection of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, a United States federal law which included a prohibition on the manufacture for civilian use of certain semi-automatic firearms that were defined as assault weapons as well as certain ammunition magazines that were defined as "large capacity". The 10-year ban was passed by the US Congress on September 13, 1994, following a close 52–48 vote in the US Senate, and was signed into law by US President Bill Clinton on the same day. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Assault_Weapons_Ban Democrats move on gun control: House due to vote on banning high-capacity magazines Some House Democrats will return early from the summer recess to advance gun control legislation, including a bill banning large ammunition magazines. If there were a lame duck Senate session this year ...

The US congress is in recess for most of December, its final day in session is Dec 12th. That is 111 days away, but the congress is on its summer break and wont be back until Sept 9th - there are a further three weeks were both houses are in recess, which leaves us with roughly 44 days where congress is in session (4 day weeks, 11 weeks in session - https://ballotpedia.org/116th_Congress_legislative_calendar)  The average length for a bill to pass is 263 days, but the shortest time a bill can be passed by both houses is a day, for urgent bills ie finance. This wouldnt be a finance bill.  The President has only vetoed 5 bills, about 450 have been passed under him. The Senate is the biggest obstacle to this passing, and I think that getting 60 votes for what will be seen as 'gun control' is not good politics for republicans in the run up to an election next year. 22 of the 34 seats in the senate that are up for reelection are republican. 13 republicans would have to cross the floor for a bill to pass the senate, or it would have to be supported by McConnell. The senate seems to be more supportive of background checks/red flag laws. There doesnt seem to be much movement on any form of gun control under the republicans, and I dont think there will be an exception here. Thanks to @emil and @anneinak for their comments.

~~~
Outside View
~~~ First piece of historical context - a base rate for this would be the number of weapon equipment ban bills that have become laws relative to the number of opportunities for such legislation. The numerator is 1, the Federal Assault Weapons Ban of 1994. [3, 4]. The denominator is hard to pin down but arguably it is very very large (e.g. every session of Congress, or every session of Congress during which gun control was a matter of public debate). Overall it is fair to say that any kind of legislative weapons ban is a very rare thing in US history. Second piece of historical context - only about 4-10% of bills become laws depending on your source [1,2]. A caveat to that is this question is not necessarily asking about a bill become a law but about passing through Congress, so the base rate should be somewhat higher but not by much.  ~~~
Inside view
~~~ Recent shooting episodes, which came in quick succession, have brought gun control on the national agenda again. There is a chance of passage in the Democratic-controlled House. There has even been some support from GOP representatives [5]. However, the Senate will be a substantial deterrent, particularly with the filibuster in place (i.e. requiring a 60+ majority). It is more likely that discussion in the Senate will center around red-flag laws (i.e. background checks) which are much more feasible (though still unlikely). As for Trump, he is likely to sign it given that he pushed an executive ban on bump stocks through the government last year. All in all, both the Outside and Inside view point toward a very low likelihood. A counterargument may be that a magazine ban is a lower bar and should be more likely. While I agree it is more likely than an outright weapons ban, I'd say not by much. Second amendment supporters are likely to view any kind of gun control legislation as a slippery slope. [1] https://www.huffingtonpost.com/wires/2009/08/25/the-vast-majority-of-bill_ws_268630.html)
[2] http://www.ushistory.org/gov/6e.asp
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Assault_Weapons_Ban
[4] https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/us-gun-policy-global-comparisons
[5] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/06/us/politics/congress-gun-control.html
